question_stem: The function \(f(x)\) is defined as \(f(x) = \frac{2x - 1}{x + 4}\) for \(x \neq -4\).

parts.question_text: State the equations of the asymptotes of the curve \(y = f(x)\).
parts.solution_text: The vertical asymptote occurs when the denominator is equal to zero.  Setting \(x + 4 = 0\) gives \(x = -4\).  The horizontal asymptote can be found by considering the limit as \(x\) tends to infinity:  \(\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2x - 1}{x + 4} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2 - \frac{1}{x}}{1 + \frac{4}{x}} = \frac{2}{1} = 2\). Therefore, the equations of the asymptotes are \(x = -4\) and \(y = 2\).
